security: Releasing informant information could potentially endanger the informant and compromise future investigations. 'Tampa requested not to make any inquiry of any informant relative to the visit of CARLOS and JOSEPH MARCELLO and their respective wives, as is Miami, due to the fact that this would immediately identify the informant who furnished this information.'
summary: The FBI New Orleans field office sends photographs of Carlos Marcello to the Tampa and Miami field offices for identification by informants, with specific instructions to protect the identity of the informant who provided the initial information.
summary_one_paragraph: On November 18, 1966, the New Orleans FBI field office (SAC, NO) transmitted an Airtel via airmail to the Director of the FBI, with copies to the Tampa and Miami field offices, enclosing two photographs each of Carlos Marcello. The purpose was to have informants, including TP 120-C, in Tampa and Miami identify Marcello without revealing the source who initially reported on Carlos and Joseph Marcello's visit, as this would compromise the informant's identity. The document includes routing information, file numbers, and approval signatures.
title: Santo Trafficante, Jr., aka
